last_post.content:
Here is a fascinating line of thinking for the #ChatGPT and #AIart #copyright lawsuits: the paper's author points out that LLMs are not simply cutting-and-pasting text from the training data to the output. Instead, the LLM is a matrix of token-following-token probabilities that are "unimaginably complex".

Is that matrix of unimaginable complexity creating derivative works? Because the output wasn't created by a human, can it gain official copyright protection?

title: Pluralistic: This “inflation” is different (14 Dec 2022) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
Rather, it's caused by things like wars and pandemics (which reduce the supply of key inputs and goods), mass deaths (which reduce the workforce), lack of daycare and other policies (which reduce it further), and more:

https://pluralistic.net/2022/12/14/medieval-bloodletters/#its-the-stupid-economy

16/

Here he echoes Joseph Stiglitz and Regmi Ira, who compare interest rate hikes to bloodletting. If the patient gets worse, you're not bleeding them enough. If they get better, the bloodletting clearly saved them. If they die, well, some diseases are simply incurable:

https://rooseveltinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/12/RI_CausesofandResponsestoTodaysInflation_Report_202212.pdf

For Stiglitz and Ira, interest rate hikes don't address inflation because inflation isn't caused by too much money.

I am going to keep posting about this until we get to 100,000 signatures.

So,you have seen posts like this before and you are getting bored of seeing it. However, the rate of increase in the number of votes is decreasing. I know we can do this, so please help me out.

As I write there are 87,960 signatures. The linear trend line of signatures from Tuesday 31 January gives an equation of
y = 1076.9x + 82277.
That means the date for hitting 100,000 votes has drifted out three days to Wednesday 15 February. I know we can do better than this. The last we thing we want is the petition to remove LGBT content from the curriculum to be debated and our opinion not to be heard.

Please sign if you are in the UK and please boost if you are not.

May I take this opportunity to thank each and everyone of the 900 people that have boosted this post so far. ❤️ ❤️

WHY WE'RE NOT POST-COVID

No, the pandemic is not over. The World Health Organization says we're still in a pandemic. WHO declared the public health emergency on 30 January 2020 and a pandemic on 11 March 2020, and it's the entity that gets to decide it's over--not you, me, or President Biden. Days ago, WHO held a meeting to discuss COVID, and it determined the pandemic remains a public health emergency of international concern.

title: Elon Musk Is Pulling the Plug on a Tool That Made Twitter Great

last_post.content: Twitter's API is part of what made the platform great. What we’ll be left with after free access ends is a Twitter that’s less fun, less open, less interesting, and more expensive—but with just as many problems as before, EFF's @jgkelley writes in Slate. https://slate.com/technology/2023/02/twitter-free-api-ending.html

title: What we are really askingthe model is the following question: Given thestatistical distribution of words in the vast publiccorpus of (English) text, what words are mostlikely to follow the sequence “The first person towalk on the Moon was ”? A good reply to thisquestion is “Neil Armstrong”.

last_post.content:
"What we are really asking [an #LLM] is the following question: Given the statistical distribution of words in the vast public corpus of (English) text, what words are most likely to follow the sequence “The first person to walk on the Moon was ”? A good reply to this question is “Neil Armstrong”.

title: Letterform Archive expands its Online Archive to include full, original publications from the Bauhaus School

last_post.content:
#design #DesignHistory #books #magazines #Bauhaus

'Letterform Archive announces a significant update to its Online Archive with the digitization of fourteen Bauhaus books and three years of Bauhaus magazines. The publications are now available online as free resources to anyone in the world.'
